bib_record.title: Measurement of the 80Se(gamma,n) reaction with linearly polarized gamma rays

free_txt: Experiment performed at HIgS facility
at Duke University, generated circularly polarized
and monoenergetic photon beams.
Angle-integrated differential cross-section data were
integrated with respect to excitation energy. Due to
the 600-keV energy threshold, measured cross section
data were extrapolated from the maximum excitation
energy of the measurements to the theoretical maximum
excitation energy.
Three liquid-scintillation detectors filled
with BC501-A fluid were placed around the target.
The front of each detector was covered with a 2.4 mm
thick lead disk to desensitize the scintillators to
the prompt gamma ray flash.
Position of individual detectors with respect to
sample and gamma ray beam was as follows
Detector   Distance(cm)     Theta(deg)     Phi(deg)
The number of photons incident on the target
was measured with the thin plastic scintillator paddle
that was located upstream.
Experiment performed at HIgS facility
at Duke University, generated circularly polarized
and monoenergetic photon beams.
The HIgS facility produces a quasi-
monoenergetic Compton backscattered photon beam
tunable in wide energy range with either linear or
circular polarization. A high-flux photon beam is
created by colliding relativistic electron beam
bunches, circulating in a storage ring, with photon
pulses inside the high-power optical cavity of a free-
electron laser. The 15.6-MeV gamma ray beam was
produced by Compton backscattering of FEL photons with
wavelength 454.7 nm off 624-MeV electrons. The gamma
ray beam at the HIGS is pulsed with a bunch width of
300 ps FWHM and a period of 180 ns between pulses.
This time structure enables neutron energy
determinations by time-of-flight methods.
Energy of emitted neutrons were determined
using time-of-flight. Excellent pulse shape properties
of BC501-A was used to identify neutrons. Gamma ray
peak position was used as internal time reference.
The selenium target consisted of
2.99 g of enriched 80Se powder, encased in a plastic
cylinder. The volume containing the 80 Se powder was
20-mm diameter x 5-mm long.The front and back ends of
the plastic cylinder were 1.5 mm thick each, and the
surrounding circular wall was 5.5 mm thick.
Systematic uncertainty in plastic paddle
efficiency
Systematic uncertainty in neutron detector
efficiency
Systematic uncertainty in neutron effective
transmission
Total systematic uncertainty
The total uncertainties reflect both the
totalsystematic uncertainty of the differential
cross-section measurements and the extrapolation
uncertainty, added in quadrature.
Data taken from tab.3 of the reference
